Name of the event: FGDs with MSMEs – Supply-side
Date and venue: 06/06, Venue: Babylon Hotel in Baghdad
Highlights:
• Recognition of the importance of climate-smart materials and green energy is gradually
increasing, though the process is slow.
• The prevalent corruption and bureaucratic inefficiencies significantly hamper industry growth
and need targeted intervention.
• The banking system's inefficiencies and high transaction costs need to be addressed to
facilitate smoother trade.
• Enhanced collaboration between the government, private sector, and educational institutions
can foster greater awareness and adoption of green technologies.
• Developing robust financial mechanisms and incentives can accelerate the shift towards
sustainable construction practices.
• Implementing strict quality control standards for imported materials and supporting local
production can improve overall material quality.
• Establishing industrial zones and offering financial incentives for green energy adoption can
drive industry growth.
• Universities and local authorities can play a pivotal role in educating both consumers and
industry professionals about the benefits and advancements in green technologies.
• Promoting workshops and capacity-building programs can equip companies with the necessary
skills and knowledge to implement modern construction practices.
Summary:
1. Current state and practices:
o Climate smart materials: There is a lack of awareness among engineers and ministries
about the use of climate-smart materials. For example, for a participating company,
it took three years to promote the use of plastic steel for plumbing.
o Imported Materials: Commonly imported materials include floors, windows, pipes,
steel, fibers, cements, ceramics, porcelain, and tiles. However, importing materials
faces challenges due to poor quality control and high testing costs handled by
private labs.
2. Challenges:
o Corruption: Corruption significantly affects the industry, particularly in registering
factories and obtaining necessary permits.
o Exchange rate: Fluctuations in the exchange rate create pricing instability. Prices do
not revert to original levels once increased.

o Banking system: Iraq's banking system is inefficient, with transfers taking 10-20
days, increasing costs and delaying projects. High fees and financial hurdles in
international transactions complicate import processes.
o Consumer convincing: Convincing consumers of the benefits of modern materials
and green energy is difficult, especially due to initial poor experiences with new
technologies, e.g. solar energy.
o Transportation: Problems with transporting materials from outside Iraq add to the
logistical challenges.
o Quality Control: Absence of robust quality checkpoints at the borders or at the
ports which allows substandard and low-quality materials to access the country,
which contributes to the widespread of low-quality materials in the market.
3. Recommendations:
o Consumer awareness: Increase awareness through workshops and events,
highlighting the long-term benefits of green energy and modern materials.
o Government role: Government should implement laws to create industrial zones,
support factories, and standardize green technologies for residential construction.
o Financial support: Provide financial incentives and easier access to finance for
consumers to adopt green energy solutions.
o Standards and qualifications: Develop and enforce standards for individual houses
and ensure workers are properly qualified.
Name of the event: FGDs with Input suppliers and service providers – Supply-side
Date and venue: 09/06, Venue: Arjaan Hotel - Erbil
Highlights:
• There is a clear growth in the adoption of solar energy, indicating a positive trend towards
renewable energy sources in Iraq.
• The use of advanced isolation techniques and a focus on water reduction in construction
reflects an increasing awareness of and response to environmental sustainability.
• The lack of skilled technicians highlights a need for targeted educational programs and
certification processes to bridge the gap between engineering knowledge and practical
application.
• Consumer behaviour focused on cost-saving over quality needs to be addressed through
comprehensive awareness campaigns that emphasize the long-term benefits and savings of
quality installations.
• Enhancing collaboration between the government, NGOs, and private sector can lead to more
effective implementation of climate-smart solutions.
• Developing robust training programs for applicators and technicians can ensure higher quality
installations and greater consumer trust in these technologies.

• Establishing clear quality standards for construction materials and providing financial
incentives can stimulate the market for sustainable construction practices.
• Streamlining the registration and import processes for businesses can reduce costs
Summary:
1. Current state
o Solar energy: Solar technologies are increasingly available and in demand in Iraq,
with a 50% rise in consumer interest in the last three years. Over 50 companies now
work with solar panels, up from a few in 2018.
o Isolation techniques: Focus on thermal and hydro isolation starting from basements
to roofs, using different materials for each step.
o Water reduction: Innovations in materials aim to reduce water usage in
construction by 50%.
o Companies indicated that efforts to raise awareness among individuals about
climate-smart construction solutions have shifted focus to applicators (installers)
who can educate consumers.
o The efficacy of isolation techniques is demonstrated through re-testing with thermo
cameras.
o Training and certification programs are needed to improve the skills of technicians
and applicators, who play a crucial role in the adoption of these technologies.
2. Challenges:
o Quality and cost: A significant portion of consumers prioritize low costs over
quality, which impacts the overall effectiveness and durability of the constructions.
o Technical workforce: There are enough engineers but a shortage of skilled
technicians for installation, highlighting a gap in the workforce.
o Regulatory and logistical issues: Businesses face challenges in registration and
import processes, particularly in navigating the bureaucratic requirements and high
transport costs between different regions of Iraq.
o Government Support: Need for government and NGO intervention in cost-sharing,
providing loans, and setting quality control standards for imported materials.
3. Recommendations:
o Consumer education: Consumers need to be informed about the long-term cost
benefits and dangers of not using proper insulation.
o Government policies: Implement minimum quality requirements for imported
materials and support training programs for technicians.
o Incentives: Financial incentives, such as loans and subsidies, can encourage the
adoption of climate-smart solutions.
o Promotion and outreach: Use social media, workshops, and direct engagement with
engineers and applicators to spread awareness of the benefits of these
technologies.
Regional practices: Highlight the successful adoption of green energy in Saudi Arabia and
Gulf countries where higher initial costs lead to long-term savings. Governments in these
regions offer incentives and partial loans for adopting green technologies.

Name of the event: FGDs with MSMEs – Supply-side
Date and venue: 10/06, Venue: Mosul Space
Takeaways and Highlights:
• Main Projects: The primary projects discussed by the attendees involve residential houses and
apartment building. There is a trend towards shifting from horizontal to vertical expansion in
Iraq, due to the rapid population growth averages.
• Migration Effects: During the displacement period (2014-2018), most residents of Mosul
moved to Erbil, where they became accustomed to residential complexes. These complexes
offer several benefits, such as security, sustainability, and adequate space for families.
• Modern Design Trends: There is a current trend towards implementing environmentally
friendly designs in homes due to the reduced size of residences compared to the past. Gardens
are now often designed within the house instead of outside, with a good adoption rate.
• Regulatory Non-Compliance: There is direct interaction between citizens and service providers
without adhering to laws and regulations. Generally, contractors submit different layouts from
those actually constructed to municipalities, to ease obtaining construction permissions.
Approximately 90% of the layouts with the municipality do not match the actual construction.
• Discrepancies in the layouts (design): The discrepancies are mainly associated with the area.
Usually, the municipality only checks on street cleanliness and verifies ownership documents
– a situation that’s applicable to Iraq, but not Kurdistan, where inspections are more thorough.
The municipality does not strictly follow the original standards and regulations, due to
outdated and stringent nature of them, which, if fully enforced, would make the acquiring of
construction permissions very difficult.
• Green Space Mismanagement: There is also improper investment in green spaces, with
residential complexes being built instead. Additionally, the selected locations are far from the
city centre and lack nearby services.
• Outdated Government Tenders: The government tenders do not enforce the use of the newly
eco-friendly materials, which are sustainable. Corruption also influences the evaluation and
study of these tenders, which is an issue.
• Consultancy Requirements: Unlike in the Kurdistan Region, there’s no enforcement to assign
consulting offices to variety of construction projects in Mosul.
• Skilled Labor: Mosul has a high availability of skilled labour at competitive prices, among the
lowest in Iraq.
• Energy Consumption: One-third of Iraq's electricity production is used for water heating in
winter due to outdated, energy-intensive water heaters. There are no regulations to control or
specify the standards of these devices during import and installation.

Summary:
1. Current state
o Solar energy: There’s a leap towards adopting the climate-smart practices,
especially the solar energy due to the high prices of electricity recently, despite
being under ambition.
o Awareness: Citizens often spend significant amounts on luxurious house facades
instead of investing in energy-efficient modifications like solar panels.
2. Challenges
o Cost and Material Prices: The rising cost of building materials is a major obstacle.
o Customer Awareness: Customers often reject modern solutions that may be costlier
initially but offer long-term benefits, preferring traditional materials and methods
due to cost concerns and lack of awareness. For example, ordinary blocks are cheaper
than insulated blocks – which is what many customers look at first.
o Direct Contracting: Many customers bypass engineering offices, opting for
contractors without engineering qualifications. Approximately 50% of middle-class
homes in Mosul are built without engineering office input, mainly due to a lack of
awareness. Which of course, leads to several problems in the future in terms of the
quality and safety of structure as well as the overuse of construction materials which
impose an extra cost.
o Obstacles to Modern Building Practices: The main obstacles to adopting modern
building practices, such as solar energy and thermal insulation, are twofold. The first
obstacle is the high initial cost of equipping and implementing these technologies.
The second is cultural, as many people perceive solar energy as a luxury rather than
a necessity. Therefore, increasing awareness can lead to a positive and fundamental
change in this area.
o Trust Issues: Another barrier is the lack of trust between citizens and companies
providing these modern technologies, largely due to their limited use in residential
settings.
3. Recommendations and Suggestions
o Mandatory Consultancy: A consulting body should be appointed for every project,
whether state or privately funded, to ensure the safety and quality of construction
across Iraq.
o Construction Permits: Address the issue of building permits, especially for areas less
than 200 square meters, though the impact of such a solution remains uncertain.
o Updating Construction Laws: Local building laws should be updated to be more
flexible and aligned with market realities.
o Public Awareness on the use of Engineering offices/engineers: There should be
efforts to educate citizens on the positive role of engineers and engineering firms in
construction. The misconception that hiring professionals increases costs should be
countered, emphasizing that professional input ensures sustainability and cost
efficiency.

o Promoting Sustainable Practices: Engineering offices should actively educate clients
on the benefits of sustainable building practices, such as solar energy, rather than
focusing solely on costs.
o Incentives for Solar Energy: To encourage the adoption of solar energy, installations
should be offered on installment plans with government support, tailored to
consumption levels. This could serve as a temporary alternative to the widespread
private generators in Iraq, which considered one of the most contributors to
increased GHG emissions in Iraq.
o Promoting Success Stories: Sharing successful case studies and stories of
adopting modern and sustainable construction practices and their positive
environmental and financial impacts can significantly contribute to increasing the
adoption of these technologies, especially in the Mosul province.

Objective: To stimulate decent work opportunities for young women and
men while addressing urgent need for affordable housing,
especially for lower income and vulnerable people in Iraq.
Duration: 4 years (2023-2027)
Partners: United Nations Human Settlements Programme (UN-Habitat),
International Labour Organization (ILO), and
International Trade Centre (ITC)
Budget: Euro 20 million
Building Equitable and Inclusive Transformation (BEIT)
Towards Decent Work and Affordable Housing in Iraq

WHO
is implementing the project?
United Nations Human Settlements Programme (UN-Habitat): UN-Habitat is mandated by the United Nations
General Assembly to promote socially and environmentally sustainable towns and cities with the goal of
providing adequate shelter for all.
International Labour Organization (ILO): The mandate and vision of the International Labour Organization
(ILO) is to promote decent work for all workers and social justice, regardless of where they work.
International Trade Centre (ITC): ITC is the joint agency of the World Trade Organization (WTO) and the
United Nations. ITC is the only international development agency fully dedicated to supporting micro, small
and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs) to enable them to benefit from trade.
WHAT
is the project about?
Component 1: The ILO is working to integrate an
Employment Intensive Investment Programme and Local
Resource Based approaches, with a focus on the inclusion
of women and sustainable financing, into the National
Public Works Programme in three Iraqi governorates. This
involves identifying financing sources, conducting analyses
for programme design, drafting policies and manuals, and
strengthening government capacities in areas like child
labour prevention, labour governance, and women's
empowerment and inclusion in housing and construction.
Component 2: UN-Habitat strives to support the Iraqi government in building the capacity to address housing
challenges by developing sustainable financial tools, creating an enabling regulatory and legislative
framework, and building the knowledge and skills to deliver effective affordable housing policies and
programs. The BEIT initiative promotes integrated approaches to affordable green housing in two pilot areas,
aiming to create jobs, empower SMEs, and mitigate climate change impacts in the housing sector.
Component 3: The ITC aims to enhance trade-led private sector engagement in Iraq, focusing on climate-
smart construction and housing. Strategies include developing a private-public sector development roadmap,
forming SME cluster alliances for climate-resilient housing retrofit, creating vocational training aligned with
green solutions, and improving the business environment and policy framework for trade and investment in
construction services.
Component 4: The ILO works to empower social partners for better labour market outcomes and working
conditions through social dialogue and capacity building. Activities include developing a national
coordination mechanism for collective bargaining rights, enhancing the influence of social partners in the
labour market, especially in construction, and promoting awareness of rights and obligations related to
organizing and collective bargaining.

The International Trade Center (ITC) and Mosul Space are collaborating to host a Sustainability and Reconstruction Meetup on August 21, 2024. - Short, impromptu presentations (5-10 minutes) from attendees
- Live note-taking to highlight relationships and commonalities
- Open discussion and networking opportunities

- Universities and research institutions
- Local businesses and entrepreneurs

- NGOs and international organizations

4.5.2 OUTCOME THREE: DESCRIPTION
Improved business environment and participation of local MSMEs and investors in the construction sector.
Activities under Outcome 3 aim to address challenges in the construction sector that limit the potential contributions
of small businesses to employment generation, the creation of affordable and sustainable housing, and economic
growth and diversification. These include support for the improvement of capacities of firms, the efficiency of value
chains, and environment to access and operate in the construction and housing sectors in Iraq. Due to their
dynamism, MSMEs in particular stand to make a major contribution to the improvement of the housing sector and
will be assisted in this through project’s activities on strategy design and implementation, local organisation, and
training and capacity building. ITC’s experience in working with the private sector and other stakeholders, and
facilitating public-private collaboration on strategy design and implementation, firm-level capacity building, value
chain coordination, and trade and investment policy and regulatory reform, and trade and investment to drive
sustainable and inclusive growth will be leveraged in implementing these elements of the project. Specific attention
will be given to ensuring that safety standards and disaster resilience are promoted.
4.5.3 OUTCOME THREE: OUTPUTS AND ACTIVITIES
Output 3.1: Strengthened partnership between Iraqi public and private stakeholders to design and implement a
green sustainable construction sector development strategy.
A sustainable sector development strategy is needed to provide a solid basis for a strengthened construction sector
by setting common policy priorities and coordinating key actors. In order to maximise the impact of the strategy, the
project includes activities under Output 3.1 on value chain analysis, participatory strategy design, the establishment
or strengthening of an effective public-private sector coordination structure responsible for implementation,
technical and advisory on implementation management including monitoring and resource mobilization.
The strategy will be comprehensive in scope, addressing the development of products and services directed at
increasing productivity, promoting investment, nurturing innovation, enhancing value addition, and improving the
institutional and regulatory environment.
The strategy will address issues that constrain competitiveness and private sector development, while ensures that
developmental objectives are targeted. To this end, the strategy design process will follow an inclusive and
participative approach to ensure that all stakeholders are consulted and have ownership over the resulting strategy
and implementation plan. Women empowerment considerations will be incorporated into the analysis of challenges
and opportunities throughout the sector development strategy, highlighting the needs and priorities of women-led
MSMEs and key recommendations. To this end, women-led MSMEs and relevant public and private sector
organisations representing women in the private sector will be consulted and interviewed during the strategy design
process. Through this approach, the strategy will reflect their needs and priorities by elaborating specific and tailored
recommendations in the action plan.
Findings and recommendations from other existing endorsed plans will be integrated and further developed. A
capacity-building approach will be adopted along the process, with the aim of strengthening the capacity of national
partners to formulate, manage and implement their own strategy.
53
The project will work with stakeholders to design the detailed strategy, including a five-year plan of action, that
allocates responsibilities, and specifies timelines and targets. As a result, the Government of Iraq will own a strategy
for the construction sector that is specific and measurable to ensure well-managed implementation, accountability,
and that the desired results are achieved. These activities will be delivered directly through the project, with the
potential involvement of external experts in an advisory capacity.

Activity 3.1.1: Define strategy design process, roles, including the focal point organization and person, and work
plan.
Define strategy design process, roles, including the focal point organization and persons, and develop a work plan.

for the duration of the design process.
In collaboration with project partners, this activity would entail as well the identification (or formation) of a sector-
level coordination platform to guide the strategy design process and subsequent implementation. This coordination

Activity 3.1.2: Conduct comprehensive background research on the structure and functioning of the value chain,

Conduct comprehensive background research on the structure and functioning of the construction value chain,

54

participation, closing the skills gaps, developing business models and measures to foster the adoption of

Successful implementation management of a strategy ensures that all relevant institutions and partners are enabled
to implement activities within a coherent framework. Accordingly, strategy implementation management support
focuses assisting such a framework and providing specialized tools and advice to ensure successful implementation
and monitoring of activities outlined in the Plan of Action (PoA) of the Strategy. The project’s intervention will aim
to capacitate the Secretariat of the established sector coordination structure, so as to guarantee that initiatives

capacity building will be provided as required. Tools and organisational best practices in achieving strategy

Output 3.2: Improved opportunities and capacities of supply chain actors for private sector-led affordable, quality

over a multi-annual process, increased productivity, cost reduction and enhanced compliance with environmental

programme has been implemented in over 15 countries and 10 value chains and can be adapted to serve any

Activities Narrative:
Activity 3.2.1: Climate-Smart Housing Retrofit Consumer Research, Product-Market combination, and selection of
target areas.
Building on activities under output 3.1, ITC and partners plan to conduct market research on climate-smart housing
retrofit solutions and affordable housing construction in Iraq, with a focus on energy efficiency and climate
adaptation, particularly in high-temperature environments. The research will identify options for new retrofit
products to be offered by MSMEs in the fields of energy-efficient appliances / air conditioning, water efficiency, heat
insulation, and renewable energy solutions within an affordable budget range (e.g. $5,000 - $10,000 package

intervention while setting clear selection criteria balancing vulnerability and market requirements. Possible
partnership to serve housing fund recipients will be also explored (e.g. housing fund beneficiaries). These insights
will inform subsequent activities under outputs 3.2 and 3.3, empowering local SMEs to offer tailored, cost-effective,
and sustainable solutions to address climate challenges while fostering economic growth in the construction and
energy sectors.
Activity 3.2.2: Organize market awareness events on innovative climate-smart services and establish MSME
alliances to enhance collaboration, knowledge sharing, and collective bargaining power, strengthening the sector.
This multifaceted activity will create two local associations of construction MSMEs (“Alliances”) that will be both
connected with construction material / innovative climate-smart solution suppliers, relevant service providers (e.g
architectural design services, housing finance) and potential consumers. By creating these alliances, we aim to
provide smaller firms with a platform to collectively address challenges, share insights, and negotiate more

emphasizing energy efficiency and eco-friendly practices.
ITC will actively engage local construction MSMEs and community representatives in target areas to develop
sustainable development plans. These plans will prioritize energy-efficient and eco-friendly practices through clear
goal-setting, actionable steps, and capacity-building initiatives. They will also promote respect of construction
standards, safety and disaster resilience. We will identify specific needs for training and material support through
comprehensive needs assessments. Ongoing monitoring and documentation will ensure adaptability and provide
valuable insights for the construction sector's long-term sustainability in these areas. These plans will be aligned with
the national strategy devised under 3.1 and will support its implementation locally.
Activity 3.2.4: Definition of the technical designs for the climate-adaptive retrofit products and associated quality
standards and certification processes in partnership with government and private sector.
The implementation of this activity involves a collaborative effort bringing together local and international
architects, builders, material suppliers, academia, government, and other stakeholders. This collective initiative will

effective technical designs and packages tailored for Iraqi Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs) to retrofit
existing buildings. These designs may encompass various sustainability elements, including enhanced insulation,
energy efficiency, sealing, shade structures, natural ventilation, reflective painting, cool roofing, and solar energy

solutions. The goal is to create standardized and pre-agreed fixed-cost packages making sustainable retrofitting
accessible and affordable for MSMEs while addressing climate challenges. To ensure technical quality, the initiative

Activity 3.2.5: Creation of an incentive program and social marketing for the adoption of the climate adaptation
retrofit packages by consumers.
More than 200 households are set to benefit from climate-adaptive housing retrofit packages delivered by MSME
members of the Alliances, showcasing their tangible value and the economic returns achieved through energy
efficiency savings. To encourage early adoption and utilize these initial households as model homes to convince
neighbours, we will introduce an incentive program covering 50% of the retrofit costs for the first 50 families in each

interest, and demonstrate the economic returns of this sustainable investment to the broader community.
Activity 3.2.6: Support to commercial delivery of the housing retrofit packages by local Alliance MSMEs building
on capacity strengthening effort under output 3.3 and quality insurance and certification mechanisms set under
activity 3.2.4.
This activity focuses on providing comprehensive support to the commercial delivery of housing retrofit packages by
local Alliance Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs). Building upon the capacity strengthening efforts
outlined in Output 3.3 and guided by the quality assurance and certification mechanisms established in Activity 3.2.4,

implement the retrofit packages developed under Activity 3.2.4. Collaborative partnerships with material suppliers
are integral, facilitating the exchange of expertise and technical standards required for effective package installation.
Additionally, a robust certification mechanism, a product of Activity 3.2.4, guarantees that only certified installers
are engaged and that external verification maintains the quality of installation at the highest standards. This
coordinated approach reinforces the successful and reliable commercial delivery of housing retrofit solutions while
bolstering the capacity of local enterprises and entrepreneurs.

green and innovative practices in their operation.

young entrepreneurs, to incorporate green and innovative practices into their operations. This output recognizes
the importance of enhancing the skills and knowledge of entrepreneurs to drive sustainability and innovation within
the local business landscape. Here are some key points and strategies outlined in this output:
The project acknowledges that small businesses, especially micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs),

mainstream climate smart solutions in Iraq.

Output 3.4: Improved regulatory and legal framework for access to and provision of construction and housing
services in Iraq.
An enabling framework for service providers (businesses and investors) to engage in construction and housing
services in Iraq has the potential to contribute to improvements in housing affordability and sustainability, including
through the more active involvement of MSMEs in these sectors.
Access to construction and housing services and effective functioning of such service providers is instrumental to
addressing Iraq’s housing crisis. Increasing opportunities for service providers in this sector to operate in Iraq and
the functioning of various service providers in this space would allow for a more competitive sector – thus creating
the impetus for better quality and competitively priced services within the housing and construction sector in Iraq.
A preliminary assessment revealed restrictions in the ability of service providers in this sector to operate across the
modes of supply of services (i.e. the four modes through which services are traded: Cross-border trade – Mode 1;
Consumption abroad - Mode 2; Commercial presence – Mode 3; and Temporary movement of natural persons –
Mode 4). Restrictions were identification in the context of the setting up a commercial presence in the country,
accessing services abroad, and bringing in foreign labour/skills needed for these services. Among others, regulatory
challenges identified include the disjunct between the legal framework and practical implementation creating space
60
for uneven implementation of laws and informal mechanisms; restrictions in foreign participation in the sector,
ability for foreign ownership of land, and the lack of harmonization and coordination of procurement practices.
Activities to strengthen the regulatory and legal framework on market access for construction and housing services
in the country under Output 3.4 will assist with policy mapping, analysis and planning, dialogue and implementation
through targeted capacity building and the organisation of suitable platforms for discussion and coordination. Across
these activities, the sharing of international expertise and best practices will be led by local stakeholders to address
their concerns, progress towards the goals they set as priorities, and match the capacities of implementing
institutions.
Activities Narrative:
Activity 3.4.1: Undertake detailed mapping of regulatory and legislative measures governing the (a) entry and
operation of service providers in the housing and construction sectors in Iraq (including in terms of access to set
up/engage in operations, engagement of foreign professionals, operation and participation in public-private
partnerships in the sector), and (b) bidding/qualifying for procurement offers in housing and construction related
projects (including in terms of the process adopted to prepare, issue, and evaluate tenders, and award contracts).
The mapping of Iraq’s regulatory and legislative measures is a necessary first step to undertake a regulatory
assessment of Iraq’s construction and housing sector (Activity 3.4.2). The mapping will include both horizontal and
sectoral laws and regulations governing these sectors. Horizontal laws are those which apply to all service providers
(such as investment law, companies act, labour laws, immigration laws, land law, procurement etc.), which are likely
to include restrictions on transfer of funds, limitations on movement of people, caps on foreign equity participation,
etc.; while the sectoral laws covered those which govern the particular industry (such as construction law), as well
as at the sector-specific level which govern particular activities (such as the practice of architecture and engineering).
The objective of the mapping is to collect and tabulate all the regulations and legislations that impact Iraq’s in
preparation to undertake the regulatory assessment. Building upon the preliminary mapping undertaken,
consultations will be undertaken with relevant stakeholders to confirm/validate the laws/regulations/measures
identified and ensure that all relevant measures governing this sector including any provincial level
regulations/measures are covered in the mapping.
Activity 3.4.2: Conduct regulatory impact assessments for the regulatory/legal measures governing the entry and
operation of service providers in the housing and construction sectors in Iraq (identified from the mapping
engagement above).
The objective of this activity is to critically assess the effects of proposed and existing regulations (drawn from the
mapping exercise in Activity 3.4.1) in order to ensure that regulations are efficient and effective to achieve the overall
objective. This is because certain laws such as the regulation placing limits on foreign participation in the market,
function as a trade restrictive measure and therefore impact on services and investments in Iraq. Policy makers
should assess, when designing policies/laws/regulations, the likely impacts and consequences of such measures, and
regulatory impact assessments are a useful framework that can be adopted to assess regulations and ensure that it
meets the overarching objectives.
Accordingly, through this activity, ITC will support relevant stakeholders in Iraq to develop a framework for
undertaking regulatory impact assessments in the abovementioned sectors, drawing from the ‘OECD’s Best Practice
Principles for Regulatory Policy’. (Capacity building based on this framework will be undertaken in Activity 3.4.3
below).
Based on this framework, ITC will work with relevant institutions to select key laws/regulations/policies, as mapped
in Activity 3.4.1 above, and assess the impact of these measures so as understand whether it achieves the intended
objectives and how it impacts the operation of construction and housing services and investments into this sector.
Based on these assessments, and demand from the Government of Iraq, technical assistance can then be provided
to support Iraq’s policy makers to undertake necessary policy and regulatory reforms.
61
Activity 3.4.3 Provide capacity building for officers in relevant institutions on undertaking regulatory impact
assessments – to be applied for future regulatory developments – including through development of a technical
guide and practical training sessions.
Guidelines will be formulated based on the strategy discussed above on undertaking regulatory impact assessments
for the construction/housing sector related laws/regulations/policies. These guidelines will serve to function as a
toolkit that can be used for officers for existing and future laws/regulations/policies – with the objective of
contribution to efforts to promote evidence-based policy making.
Capacity building sessions will be organized for relevant institutions based on these guidelines; and practical sessions
held with relevant officers by working with ITC on the selected measures for the assessment under Activity 3.4.2.
Activity 3.4.4: Undertake diagnostic assessment of the alignment of the procurement framework governing
construction and housing sectors with international guidelines/best practices governing transparency, integrity,
and accountability of procurement processes.
Preliminary analysis undertaken revealed a lack of harmonization and coordination on procurement practices across
government organizations – with regard to procurement, methods, information contained in tender documents,
advertising periods, etc. With regards to procurement within the construction and housing sectors, it is important
for strong coordination and alignment between the activities of the Ministry of Planning and Development
Cooperation (which is the main agency responsible for public contracts in Iraq) and the Ministry of Construction,
Housing and Public Municipalities (which oversees procurement of construction services). An assessment
undertaken by OECD in 2008 reviewed the general public procurement framework and provided pertinent
interventions to enhance transparency, integrity, and accountability. Since then, further developments have taken
place in the regulatory framework governing public procurement.
Having in place a well-functioning public procurement framework that promotes transparency and accountability is
an important factor to attract investments into the sector and ensure that quality services are made available for
construction and housing services in the country. In this context, drawing from international guidelines/best
practices in relation to public procurement, drawing from the WTO’s Government Procurement Agreement (GPA),
the EU's Integrity Pact Toolbox, among others, as well as sector specific guidelines such as the Construction Sector
Transparency Initiative, to build understanding and capacitate stakeholders to work towards a more conducive and
enabling public procurement framework.
Linked with the capacity building initiatives under Activity 3.4.5, ITC will work with relevant institutions to undertake
an assessment of Iraq’s public procurement framework being adopted for construction services. The assessment will
review the regulatory framework and process adopted in place to prepare, issue and evaluate tenders, and award
of contracts for the construction and housing related projects – with the objective of assessing the extent to which
the existing framework is aligned with OECD recommendations and related international guidelines pertaining to
transparency and accountability as noted above.
Activity 3.4.5: Provide capacity building for officers on international guidelines/best practices in procurement
processes with a view to foster alignment of Iraq’s procurement processes in the housing and construction sectors.
Linked with the technical intervention in Activity 3.4.4 above, targeted capacity building initiatives will also be
undertaken for Iraq’s officers in the abovementioned ministries as well as other agencies identified from the
assessment, on best practices in public procurement with specific focus on procurement contexts for construction
and infrastructure related services. This will include training events (virtual and in-person) to raise awareness on
best practices/guidelines available in relation to public procurement and integrating these lessons into the public
procurement frameworks in Iraq for construction and housing services.
Activity 3.4.6: Provide technical/advisory support to undertake regulatory reforms – based on the impact
assessments and diagnostic assessment.
62
Based on the results of the regulatory and diagnostic assessments undertaken through Activities 3.4.2 and 3.4.4
respectively, technical assistance can be provided for relevant government agencies, based on demand, to prioritise
and implement recommendations to facilitate regulatory and institutional reforms.
Relevant interventions can be in the form of providing technical inputs to draft/amend laws/regulations, and
strategize reforms to strengthen coordination among government agencies, improve transparency, etc.
Activity 3.4.7: Organize public-private dialogues (built into the activities covered above) to present and discuss
regulatory and policy reforms to strengthen access to the construction and housing services sectors in Iraq,
including in the context of integrating broad developmental priorities such as sustainability and digitalization into
the industry.
PPDs will be built into the technical activities to present and discuss findings, seek inputs/clarifications, and obtain
validation on policy recommendations/insights formulated.
These dialogues function as an important platform for all relevant stakeholders from public and private sectors to
be informed about the studies/analyses underway, seek buy-in from stakeholders to engage in these efforts, and
facilitate dialogue between public and private sectors on policy reforms, so as to ensure that all stakeholders are
effectively engaged in the policy formulation and implementation process.
The PPDs effectively provide an opportunity to inform the reform process through inclusive consultation as well as
to validate the results of the studies; and ensure that stakeholders are actively engaged in decision making to
strengthen the regulatory and policy framework governing the construction and housing services sector in Iraq.
Activity 3.4.8: Provide capacity building engagements for public and private sector (including economic operators,
professional associations, business associations, etc.), and the academia/civil society on market access issues
relating to services trade – with focus on the construction and housing services sector (covering issues such as the
modalities of services trade, and potential from services liberalization, technicalities of MRAs, etc.).
To ensure that all relevant stakeholders relevant for strengthening the construction and housing services sector in
Iraq are able to provide meaningful inputs and effectively engage in the reform process, it is important that these
stakeholders understand their role in the services framework and the relevance of their engagement in contributing
to a conducive business environment for these services. As explained above, there are a number of different
areas/topics which have an impact on the operation of the construction and housing services sector, and accordingly,
it is important to ensure that all these various stakeholders understand their position in this reform process.
Through this activity, capacity building engagements will be undertaken for the various stakeholders (identified
based on the mapping undertaken in Activity 3.4.1) to understand the operation of trade in services (including the
modalities, potential from services liberalization, technicalities of MRAs, etc.) and explore these concepts within the
framework of the construction and housing services sector. Targeted sessions can be held with stakeholders from
specific institutions, based on request, to dive into these concepts and build linkages with authorities in the
construction and housing sectors.
Guides, infographics and related resources will be developed under this activity, to feed into the capacity building
initiatives. This activity will also see the development of guides, infographics and other resources. The most suitable
modality of capacity building will be decided based on the needs of the stakeholders.
Output 3.5: Enhanced awareness and capacities of public and private stakeholders of the regulatory and
procedural framework for investing in the housing and construction sectors and potential for reform.
Investment is a key driver of the construction and housing sector growth in Iraq. Increased investment –
domestic and foreign – will lead to increased jobs and income for the workers in these sectors, improved
access to finance, increased efficiency, as well as greater adoption of new technologies and sustainable
business models.
63
Beyond economic fundamentals such as market access conditions, and returns on investment, investment related
administrative procedures also play a key role in investment decisions. These may include measures/procedures
related to company establishment and business registration, connecting to infrastructure, capital transfers and
payments, payment of taxes, benefitting from incentives and public programmes, among others.
Iraq has adopted legal and regulatory reforms to encourage foreign investment and improve the business climate,
including through the promulgation of the Investment Law and establishment of the National Investment
Commission (NIC). The NIC, in turn, has established a one stop shop to function as a single point of contact for
investors and facilitate the investment process through streamlined services. However, significant challenges remain
making it challenging for investors seeking to engage in the construction and housing sectors in Iraq. Some challenges
identified from the preliminary analysis include the complexity and lack of clarity of regulations, predictability of the
policy environment, lack of coordination among government agencies, lack of transparency, and the complex and
time-consuming administrative procedures to be complied with. These challenges are not unique to Iraq, and efforts
have been pursued through domestic reforms or international agreements such as the WTO Investment Facilitation
for Development (IFD) Agreement to improve transparency and streamline administrative procedures to make
investment processes easier, faster, and safer.
Accordingly, interventions are designed under Output 3.5 to strengthen Iraq’s investment facilitation measures,
drawing from international guidelines, with the objective to increase flow of domestic and foreign investment into
the housing and construction sectors.
Output 3.5 engages public and private stakeholders to improve the policy environment for facilitating investments
into the housing and construction sectors, and in turn, expanding access to housing and potential of small firms in
the sector to meaningfully contribute to job creation and facilitate sustainable industrial growth. Through targeted
activities on building awareness, assessing needs, analysing potential reforms to administrative processes and
regulations, and providing comprehensive capacity building, stakeholders will be equipped with the necessary tools
to attract and engage potential investors.
Activities Narrative:
Activity 3.5.1: Determine the core group of stakeholders for investment facilitation, including participants from
both public and private sector.
Investment facilitation measures (as reflected in the WTO IFD Agreement) cover a broad scope of laws and
regulations on various elements – and accordingly, it is crucial for the country to identify all governmental agencies
directly involved in the whole life cycle of investment at both national and sub-national levels. These agencies will
need to be part of the assessment process (undertaken in Activity 3.5.2 and 3.5.4) – and form the core stakeholder
group for implementing investment facilitation measures. In addition to the core stakeholder group, it is also
necessary to engage other stakeholders, both governmental and non-governmental, involved in the whole life cycle
of an investment – which can include foreign and domestic investors, research institutes, civil society organizations
that have a practical and ground level knowledge and experience that enables them to provide inputs from various
perspectives. Key agencies already identified include the National Investment Commission, Provincial Investment
Commission, the Ministry of Trade’s Companies Registration Department, Kurdistan Board of Investment, Chamber
of Commerce, and the Council of Ministers.
Accordingly, a mapping will be undertaken of the various government agencies linked to/relevant for overseeing the
implementation of measures/procedures set out in the WTO IFD Agreement; and identification of other relevant
stakeholders (from private sector and civil society) who can be engaged in the process. The core group of
stakeholders will occupy an important role in the needs assessment and business process analysis – as the
information collected and analysis formulated will need to be reviewed and confirmed by all relevant agencies
involved in the implementation process. The overall process will have to be led by a national coordinating agency –
which will be identified in consultation with relevant agencies.
The mapping will be undertaken through a combination of desk research, and stakeholder consultations and focus
group discussion(s) to present the mapping and seek validation/inputs from the relevant stakeholders. In addition,
64
there will be a sub-core group within the overall core stakeholder group comprising stakeholders directly engaged
in the construction and housing services industry. The sub-core group will not necessarily be mutually exclusive from
the overall core stakeholder group – as there may be overlaps in the stakeholders engaged (For instance the National
Investment Commission, and the Companies Registrar will be engaged in both groups).
These activities will be undertaken by investment facilitation expert(s) and a national investment expert (with
capacity to engage in Arabic language and build networks with relevant stakeholders).
Activity 3.5.2: Provide capacity building and awareness-raising for the core group stakeholders to enhance their
knowledge about the objectives and approaches for investment facilitation and the needs assessment.
To facilitate the assessment of investment facilitation measures under Activity 3.5.3 - capacity building initiatives
will be built in for the relevant stakeholders as identified in Activity 3.5.1 - to ensure that all stakeholders are well-
versed and capacitated to engage effectively in this process.
The Needs Assessment Guide for Investment Facilitation – formulated by the WTO to enable self-assessments – and
other related materials will be circulated to all stakeholders in advance of the assessment – with the objective of
providing a good foundation and to ensure comprehensive discussion among stakeholders.
Following this, targeted capacity building sessions will be organized in collaboration with the national coordinating
agency and the core stakeholder group to build understanding on the context of investment facilitation and related
measures, and process for strengthening investment facilitation using the Needs Assessment Guide as a template.
Technical sessions will then be facilitated on each of the sections of the Needs Assessment Guide for Investment
Facilitation – to work through each provision, provide examples on how each provision can be implemented, and
discuss its application in Iraq.
Through these sessions, the objective will be to ensure that all stakeholders relevant for the investment facilitation
process are well-versed on the relevant matters and able to provide solid and useful inputs to feed into the needs
assessment process effected under Activity 3.5.3.
Activity 3.5.3: Undertake a needs assessment of the investment facilitation framework in Iraq – based on the
guidelines developed based on the WTO Investment Facilitation for Development (IFD) Agreement.
At the initial training undertaken in Activity 3.5.2, participants will be invited to fill in a pre-assessment survey to
collect preliminary inputs on relevant procedures/measures, as set out in the Needs Assessment Guide formulated
by the WTO. The Needs Assessment Guide is structured into four main sections – (a) transparency of investment
measures; (b) streamlining and speeding up administrative procedures; (c) focal points, domestic regulatory
coherence and cross-border cooperation; and (d) sustainable investment. Participants will not be required to provide
comprehensive answers and may provide partial answers focusing on their areas of expertise. The survey will serve
as a foundation for group discussion in the in-country self-assessment.
Thereafter, technical support will be provided to work through and complete information on each of the sections of
the Guide and identify challenges/constraints and areas for reform. Consultations will be built into the targeted
capacity building sessions discussed in Activity 3.5.2 above, to present preliminary inputs received from the pre-
assessment survey and obtain inputs/information from the stakeholders on the relevant
laws/regulations/procedures pertaining to each of the articles covered in the section.
This will be complemented with an in-depth study based on the information collected from the stakeholder group,
further desk research and consultations, to review the laws/regulations/administrative requirements and the
practical implementation, assess challenges/constraints identified, and compile information into the needs
assessment guide. The compiled assessment will be shared with the national coordinating agency for review,
consultations held to present the findings, and seek confirmation on the information gathered and analysed
pertaining to the relevant laws/regulations/measures.
Dialogues will be organized under Activity 3.5.7 to present the findings of the assessment to the core stakeholder
group – to seek inputs and validation on the analysis of the challenges/constraints identified – and discuss potential
65
policy reforms in this regard (refer to Activity 3.5.7 for further details). The needs assessment will be further refined
based on feedback received at these dialogues.
A final report will be prepared with an overall analysis of the investment facilitation framework in Iraq,
challenges/constraints faced, and policy recommendations to streamline and strengthen investment facilitation
measures in the country.
Activity 3.5.4: Undertake a business process analysis study on the administrative/procedural steps and relevant
agencies involved in the process for investing in and setting up operations in the housing and constructions sectors
in Iraq.
The business process analysis study will, draw from the investment facilitation analysis, and then dive into the
specific administrative procedures in the housing and construction sectors, with the aim of identifying redundancies
and undue complexities, assess mechanisms, quality, and effectiveness of procedures, and propose suggestions for
practical reform.
This will entail a mapping of the value chain in the housing and construction sector, identifying relevant steps in the
investment process, procedures for setting up a company in Iraq (both as a foreign and domestic investor) in the
construction and housing industry, required authorizations and agencies in charge, time required for obtaining
authorization, fees and charges, time and costs associated with obtaining local services required to undertake
construction and related services.
The results of this mapping will also be used to feed into the formulation of a sub-core group within the core
stakeholder group set out in Activity 3.5.1; and further targeted sessions will be conducted for stakeholders in the
sub-core group pertaining directly to the construction and housing services sectors to explain the context of
investment facilitation in the framework of the particular industry. Relevant stakeholders identified from the
preliminary analysis undertaken by ITC in this regard include the Ministry of Planning and Development Cooperation,
Ministry of Labour, General Directorate of Real Estate, and the Iraqi Syndicate of Engineers.
An analysis of the application of the procedures identified from the mapping exercise will be undertaken – through
desk research, consultations/focus group discussion, etc. – to assess/identify options to streamline procedures,
enhance collaboration among agencies, reduce required authorizations, and digitize documentation requirements,
and improve transparency and reduce corruption.
A final report will be prepared to present the overall findings, detail the procedures and challenges/constraints
identified, and provide policy recommendations to streamline, build collaboration and smoothen the process in the
construction and housing sector.
The investment facilitation experts referred to above, will be supported by a local expert in the construction and
housing services sector for this activity.
Activity 3.5.5: Develop an investment guide (which can be integrated into an online platform) on the
steps/procedures to invest and set up operations in the construction and housing sectors in Iraq.
An investment guide will be developed providing step-by-step guidance for investors seeking to engage in Iraq. The
guide will detail in a logical manner – the procedures for to set up and operate a business in in Iraq – including
measures for registering labour, engaging foreign employees, registering tax profile, claiming incentives, etc.
Upon development of the investment guide – an event will be organized to present and launch the investment guide
(potentially in collaboration with events organized under Activity 3.5.8) – with the objective of showcasing and
promoting the efforts of the Iraqi Government to strengthen the investment framework for the construction and
housing sector.
Activity 3.5.6: Deliver capacity building for public and private sector stakeholders on investment facilitation and
strengthening investment frameworks, including in the context of aligning investment frameworks with emerging
trends such as sustainability and digitalization, drawing on best practices/lessons learned from other jurisdictions
– including targeted engagements for key stakeholders such as the National Investment Commission, Provincial
66
Investment Commissions, and the Kurdistan Board of Investment, among others (based on a sustained
training/capacity building plan to be developed at the start of the project).
Complementing the targeted capacity building events for the core stakeholder group on investment facilitation,
relevant training/information-sharing materials will be developed such as infographics and video clips on related
content – which can be circulated widely to reach a broader audience.
In addition, further targeted events will be organized for the core stakeholder group and other relevant stakeholders
from the public and private sectors, to explore:
- Developments in investment negotiations, covering multilateral and regional/bilateral agreements – and
relevance for Iraq, and importance of aligning investment policy to facilitate industrial development in the
country.
- Best practices/lessons learned in leveraging investment policy to facilitate transition to digital and
sustainable led industrial growth.
These events will seek to generate awareness of the public and private sector in Iraq on the importance of
refining/strengthening investment frameworks in line with emerging trends – to build competitiveness and attract
sustainable private sector investments into the country.
For the topics referred to above, the content produced will be contextualised for the construction and housing
industry in Iraq, as relevant.
To feed into these training programmes, technical briefs will be developed on the topics mentioned above, to be
shared with participants and can also be made available on online platforms to be accessible in public.
Activity 3.5.7: Organize public-private dialogues to present and discuss regulatory and procedural reforms based
on the analyses.
In order to strengthen collaboration and coordination between the public and private sectors in Iraq, and
importantly, to also ensure that private sector is engaged as an important stakeholder in the policy formulation and
implementation process in Iraq – public-private dialogues will be built in across the activities under Output 3.5.
As noted in Activity 3.5.1, 3.5.3 and Activity 3.5.4 above, public-private dialogues will be organized to present:
- the mapping of relevant stakeholders undertaken for the studies under this Output, and
- the findings of the self-assessment for investment facilitation framework in Iraq and the analysis of the
investment process in the construction and housing sector in Iraq.
These dialogues will be a forum from which to familiarize stakeholders with the interventions being undertaken to
strengthen the investment facilitation framework for the construction and housing sector in Iraq, obtain
feedback/inputs on the analysis, facilitate discussion between public and private sectors on challenges/constraints
faced and feasibility of proposed policy recommendations, and seek agreement from stakeholders on the way
forward.
Reports will be drawn upon based on each public-private dialogue organized to detail the discussion points covered
in the dialogue, agreements reached between stakeholders, and set out the next steps. These reports will function
as a record for the relevant government agencies and institutions to take action on policy reforms, and for private
sector to be able to track and follow-up on relevant matters, including providing the necessary support to facilitate
implementation of the policy reforms.
These reports, upon sign off from the main government agency, can be circulated among all participants in the
public-private dialogue.
67
Activity 3.5.8: Develop tools for facilitating sustainable investment, including domestic supplier databases of
domestic services/material providers in the construction and housing value chains, so that investors can have
easier access to information on available domestic services and suppliers.
A domestic supplier database provides information about the availability and capacity of the local suppliers so that
investors/foreign companies can have easier access to information and connect with the local suppliers. The supplier
database can be hosted on the website of the investment promotion agency (IPA), as part of IPA’s effort to promote
local suppliers and connect them to markets. The supplier database can also serve as a tool to increase transparency
in the market and help businesses assess competition and market conditions.
The tool will be made available in English and Arabic – for accessibility by local and foreign stakeholders. The
development of the database will be effected in collaboration with the IPA with the objective of capacitating relevant
officials to take ownership of the database and keep it updated.
Activity 3.5.9: Analysing and identifying countries with strong home country support measures in infrastructure/
construction/housing sectors and developing targeted initiatives to attract investors from these countries.
Some countries have strong home country support measures in infrastructure/ construction/housing sectors,
including support to identify market opportunities (business intelligence and information on regulations), support
to connect to public and private stakeholders including potential creditors, support on meeting regulatory and
sustainability standards through trainings etc. These home country measures can help increase competitiveness as
well as ensure quality delivery. Home and host country IPAs can work together to exchange information on these
support measures and develop targeted initiatives to benefit from home country measures, both for the investor
and the local communities.
ITC’s experts will organize experience sharing sessions with IPAs in selected countries (to be identified based on
research and consultations) to explore mechanisms/initiatives being implemented and exchange information in this
regard. In line with these sessions, ITC will also develop a best practice guide on relevant support measures adopted
by other selected jurisdictions and assess the feasibility for application in Iraq.
4.6 RESULTS CHAIN OUTCOME FOUR
4.6.1 OUTCOME FOUR: INTERVENTION LOGIC
If the awareness and technical capacities of social partners with regard to the right to organize, collective bargaining
and the participation in social dialogue with public actors are improved (Op 4.1), then the influence on labour
markets of employers’ and workers’ organisations involved in social dialogue with the government will be
strengthened (Oc. 4), as long as the representatives of social partners are committed to participate in the training
and technical support provided; the members are also willing to implement the technical skills acquired to
strengthen their respective organizations further; and, social partners will exert concerted effort towards using
different advocacy platforms towards ensuring their rights to organize and collective bargaining.
4.6.2 OUTCOME FOUR: DESCRIPTION
Strengthened influence on labour markets of employers’ and workers’ organisations involved in social dialogue
with the government.
The ILO has proven experience in promoting social dialogue through consultative processes between social partners
and government to shape labour markets and address labour-related issues all over the world. The ILO's work on
strengthening social partners' representativeness and institutional capacity is guided by its tripartite structure,
where representatives from governments, employers' organizations, and workers' organizations collaborate on
various programs and initiatives.
The ILO also works with governments, employers' organizations, and workers' organizations to strengthen their
institutional capacities. This includes supporting the development of effective organizational structures, internal
governance mechanisms, and strategic planning processes.
68
The ILO also supports the right of workers and employers to form and join organizations of their choice taking its
catalyst role in promoting Freedom of Association (FoA), and advocates for the recognition and protection of
collective bargaining rights. By promoting freedom of association, the ILO fosters the creation of strong and
representative workers' and employers' organizations.
Overall, the ILO's work focuses on empowering social partners to engage in social dialogue and consultative
processes. By strengthening their representativeness and institutional capacity, the ILO aims to foster inclusive and
participatory decision-making that leads to better labour market outcomes and improved working conditions for
workers.
Under this outcome, the ILO aspires to: supporting the national coordination mechanism to implement a roadmap
to strengthen the application of the right to organize and collective bargaining; and supporting institutional capacity
of the social partners to influence the labour market in the construction sector.
Furthermore, beyond Outcome four, ILO, UN-Habitat and ITC have emmeshed engagement with CSO’s throughout
the project design (outcomes one, two, and three). CSO’s will be central to engaging in policy dialogues and valued
partners on the ground - supporting with advocacy, outreach, awareness raising and implementation activities.
CSO’s will be engaged in expert consultations, participatation in roundtable and participatory planning discussions,
serve on technical working groups, and support community-level activities.
